entries.title: craigslist Charitable Fund Donates $100,000 to The Perl Foundation

entries.text: Adam Flott likes soma.fm, command line interface and Perl. Here he combines the 3.
entries.title: soma.fm command line interface

entries.text: After another long pause Peter Lavender released a new version of Padre, the Perl IDE.
entries.title: Padre 0.94 has been released...

entries.text: Tom Wyant asked C. Auguste Dupin again for help. This time with a conflict between Safe, Devel::Cover, Data::Dumper and eval. Unfortunately Dupin was just mocking him.
entries.title: The Case of the Incompatible Safe

entries.text: Dave Hodgkinson asked for some links describing how people use Emacs as a perl IDE. This is the follow-up post with the links.
entries.title: Using emacs as a perl IDE

entries.text: Yanick Champoux (yanick) gets his hands dirty while he is trying to find his way out of a new file existence test.
entries.title: A Quick Pas de Deux with Dancer
Great Picture of Catalyst Dispatch Flow

entries.text: This is a follow-up post by David Golden to his post about historical Perl 5 release cycles.
entries.title: Visualizing the Perl 5 support policy

entries.text: Mark Keating recommends some video recordings from the London Perl Workshop 2011 and Perl Oasis 2012.
entries.title: Video killed the presenting star...

entries.text: Buddy Burden describes - in a very colorful way - the process of releasing a module to CPAN and how the CPAN tester results helped him save 3 cents.
entries.title: A Tale of CPAN Testers

entries.text: chromatic saves another few minutes while building perl. It's like the 'turbo' button on old PCs. I wonder why parallelism is NOT the default?
entries.title: Speed up Perlbrew with Test Parallelism

entries.text: Viacheslav Tykhanovskyi (vti) introduces yet another templating engine.
entries.title: Text::APL - streaming and non-blocking Perl template engine

entries.text: Sergey Zasenko (und3f) uses Protocol::Redis to build a simple Redis server.
entries.title: Redis server in Perl

entries.text: Sawyer X has married Log::Dispatchouli with Moose and you got a new role.
entries.title: I love MooseX::Role::Loggable

entries.text: This is the official release note of the Rakudo Star distribution of Perl 6. It includes the Rakudo Perl 6 compiler, the Parrot Virtual Machine and a number of Perl 6 modules.
entries.title: Rakudo Star 2012.01 released

entries.text: Jonathan Worthington gives his account on why this release is so important for him.
entries.title: This month's Rakudo Star release - and what's coming next

entries.text: As Brian Meeker reports, there was no Perl content at CodeMash 2012, something I hope will be fixed next year, but there were a number of other, interesting topics.
entries.title: CodeMash 2012

entries.text: If you are part of a Perl Mongers group and wondering how could you make it better, this article might give you some ideas.
entries.title: An Oslo.pm retrospective

entries.text: Luckily I recently started to share links to articles as I notice them. That already helps me put together the newsletter. If you are interested to follow, you can do it on Google+, Facebook or Twitter.
entries.title: How to get the Perl Weekly every day?

entries.text: February 28, 2012, Ramat Gan, Israel
entries.title: Perl Workshop in Israel

entries.text: March 5-7, 2012, Erlangen, Germany
entries.title: German Perl workshop

entries.text: April 14, 2012, Catonsville, MD, USA
entries.title: DC-Baltimore Perl workshop

entries.text: June 13-15, 2012, Madison, Wisconsin, USA
entries.title: YAPC::NA

header: Finally, on this week a new version of Rakudo Star was released. This brought us a number of Perl 6 related articles.
Other than that, I am back from my vacation and I am looking forward to new ways to help people use Perl.
I'll blog about that later but now let's see the articles from the last 7 days...
subject: Craigslist donates $100,000 to TPF and Rakudo Star released on the same week!
